papers.title: Artificial Intelligence as Strange Intelligence: Against Linear Models of Intelligence
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.04986v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: We endorse and expand upon Susan Schneider's critique of the linear model of AI progress and introduce two novel concepts: "familiar intelligence" and "strange intelligence". AI intelligence is likely to be strange intelligence, defying familiar patte
papers.author: Kendra Chilson, Eric Schwitzgebel

papers.title: DeepRead: Document Structure-Aware Reasoning to Enhance Agentic Search
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05014v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: With the rapid progress of tool-using and agentic large language models (LLMs), Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is evolving from one-shot, passive retrieval into multi-turn, decision-driven evidence acquisition. Despite strong results in open-dom
papers.author: Zhanli Li, Huiwen Tian, Lvzhou Luo, Yixuan Cao, Ping Luo

papers.title: MINT: Minimal Information Neuro-Symbolic Tree for Objective-Driven Knowledge-Gap Reasoning and Active Elicitation
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05048v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Joint planning through language-based interactions is a key area of human-AI teaming. Planning problems in the open world often involve various aspects of incomplete information and unknowns, e.g., objects involved, human goals/intents -- thus leading
papers.author: Zeyu Fang, Tian Lan, Mahdi Imani

papers.title: Evaluating Large Language Models on Solved and Unsolved Problems in Graph Theory: Implications for Computing Education
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05059v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Large Language Models are increasingly used by students to explore advanced material in computer science, including graph theory. As these tools become integrated into undergraduate and graduate coursework, it is important to understand how reliably t
papers.author: Adithya Kulkarni, Mohna Chakraborty, Jay Bagga

papers.title: Towards Reducible Uncertainty Modeling for Reliable Large Language Model Agents
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05073v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) for large language models (LLMs) is a key building block for safety guardrails of daily LLM applications. Yet, even as LLM agents are increasingly deployed in highly complex tasks, most UQ research still centers on sing
papers.author: Changdae Oh, Seongheon Park, To Eun Kim, Jiatong Li, Wendi Li, Samuel Yeh, Xuefeng Du, Hamed Hassani, Paul Bogdan, Dawn Song, Sharon Li

papers.title: Optimizing Mission Planning for Multi-Debris Rendezvous Using Reinforcement Learning with Refueling and Adaptive Collision Avoidance
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05075v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: As the orbital environment around Earth becomes increasingly crowded with debris, active debris removal (ADR) missions face significant challenges in ensuring safe operations while minimizing the risk of in-orbit collisions. This study presents a rein
papers.author: Agni Bandyopadhyay, Gunther Waxenegger-Wilfing

papers.title: VERA-MH: Reliability and Validity of an Open-Source AI Safety Evaluation in Mental Health
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05088v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Millions now use leading generative AI chatbots for psychological support. Despite the promise related to availability and scale, the single most pressing question in AI for mental health is whether these tools are safe. The Validation of Ethical and
papers.author: Kate H. Bentley, Luca Belli, Adam M. Chekroud, Emily J. Ward, Emily R. Dworkin, Emily Van Ark, Kelly M. Johnston, Will Alexander, Millard Brown, Matt Hawrilenko

papers.title: Evaluating Robustness and Adaptability in Learning-Based Mission Planning for Active Debris Removal
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05091v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Autonomous mission planning for Active Debris Removal (ADR) must balance efficiency, adaptability, and strict feasibility constraints on fuel and mission duration. This work compares three planners for the constrained multi-debris rendezvous problem i
papers.author: Agni Bandyopadhyay, G\"unther Waxenegger-Wilfing

papers.title: GAMMS: Graph based Adversarial Multiagent Modeling Simulator
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05105v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: As intelligent systems and multi-agent coordination become increasingly central to real-world applications, there is a growing need for simulation tools that are both scalable and accessible. Existing high-fidelity simulators, while powerful, are ofte
papers.author: Rohan Patil, Jai Malegaonkar, Xiao Jiang, Andre Dion, Gaurav S. Sukhatme, Henrik I. Christensen

papers.title: Understanding LLM Evaluator Behavior: A Structured Multi-Evaluator Framework for Merchant Risk Assessment
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.05110v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly used as evaluators of reasoning quality, yet their reliability and bias in payments-risk settings remain poorly understood. We introduce a structured multi-evaluator framework for assessing LLM reasoning i
papers.author: Liang Wang, Junpeng Wang, Chin-chia Michael Yeh, Yan Zheng, Jiarui Sun, Xiran Fan, Xin Dai, Yujie Fan, Yiwei Cai
